utterances: Yeah, and that--you know, NPR listeners are so smart they come up with all the alternatives.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Oh yeah, oh yeah.
So, we perform our last concert in March 28th.
It was a requiem concert for all related to the music school who died, their families, friends, and also for all musician who have died during that terrible time.
But also we are preparing a concert to give an aspect of resurrection, life continues and in order to show really Haiti will rise again.
Mariano Vales, why was it important to organize performances here in Washington?
The Sainte Trinite Chamber Group, why was it important to bring them here?
Well, this is a part of an effort to bring visibility to the school and their efforts to reconstruct their facilities.
But not only that, Pere David has a brother plan to include the school as a part of the Episcopal university in Haiti.
And the school is seen as an icon, a cultural icon in Haiti.
That's the main music school, with the main auditorium.

So, the idea is, like, in three years to four years from now we'll be lucky enough to get enough funds to rebuild the school and to have a strong school of music, a performing arts facility in Haiti, which would be the first of its kind.
And, David Cesar, what do you hope comes out of this trip?
Solidarity with our brothers and sisters because we are, all of us, children of God.
So, sharing gifts, sharing talent, also possibility to invite everyone in Haiti to share our lives, to share our difficulties but also to share our joy and hope.
David Cesar is music director of the Haiti National Philharmonic Orchestra.
Mariano Vales is from the cultural affairs department of the OAS.
Bernadette Williams is a cellist with the orchestra.
Thank you all for coming in.
Thank you a lot.
Thank you.
This is Day to Day from NPR News.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
And I'm Alex Chadwick.
In Fort Carson, Colorado an American soldier is on trial for killing an Iraqi general during an interrogation that prosecutors say went too far.
This incident happened at a U.S.
military base in Iraq in November 2003.
NPR's John McChesney joins us now from Fort Carson where he's covering the court martial.
John welcome back to Day to Day.
Who's the soldier?
What's he charged with?
Well, Alex, it's Army Chief Warrant Officer, Lewis Welshofer and he's charged with murdering an Iraqi General, Abed Mowhoush, back in November of 2003.
He's accused of stuffing the general into a sleeping bag head first, wrapping the sleeping bag with electrical cord, sitting on the general, and putting his hand over his mouth periodically.
And the general died, according to the autopsy, of asphyxia.
Is there a question of fact, John?
Is the Chief Warrant Officer denying that he did indeed stuff the general in the sleeping bag or is it just a question of whether or not that's what killed him?
Mr.

Welshofer took the stand yesterday and he said that his technique, he thinks, was an interpretation of a stress position, which was authorized by Lieutenant General Ricardo Sanchez who was in charge of the Iraqi forces at this time.
You have to understand that Mowhoush was severely beaten by Iraqi nationals a couple of days before he was put in this sleeping bag and put through this technique.
He had five broken ribs.
He was incredibly badly bruised, because we saw photographs of him here in the courtroom.
Welshofer claims he didn't know that, didn't know he had broken ribs and so couldn't be responsible for that.
But other witnesses who appeared and talked about Welshofer said that the general could barely walk when he came to the interrogation room that day.
So the defense, basically, is this guy died of a heart attack during a fairly severe interrogation, but the interrogation didn't actually cause his death.
Well, the defense says he died of a heart attack.
That it was accidental.
He had an enlarged heart, it was a natural condition, and when he was put in the sleeping bag the stress caused him to have a heart attack.
So it was accidental.
The prosecution and the man who wrote the autopsy report said he died of suffocation, that he died of asphyxia.
So where does the trial go from here, John?
Well, the prosecution has rested.
The defense will present more witnesses today.
If they get through those witnesses, the panel will go out to determine guilt and if they find him guilty he could be in prison for life.
NPR's John McChesney reporting from Fort Carson, Colorado at the trial of Army Chief Warrant Officer, Lewis Welshofer, who's accused of murdering an Iraqi general during an interrogation in Iraq.
John, thank you.
Thank you, Alex.
This is DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
The syndicated cartoon strip The Boondocks is one of the controversial to emerge in recent years.
Its creator, Aaron McGruder, has adapted his racially conscious strip for television in a series starting Sunday night on the Cartoon Network.
Here's TV critic Andrew Wallenstein.
ANDREW WALLENSTEIN reporting:
It's hard to think of a famous person Aaron McGruder hasn't scandalized in The Boondocks cartoon.
He's lambasted everyone from Condoleezza Rice to Spike Lee.
In the confines of a static four-panel strip, Boondocks provides a quick blast of humor.
But stretched to 30 minutes in motion, ""The Boondocks"" amounts to a surprising misfire.
It's not that they drastically alter the original.
Boondocks fans will still recognize their favorite characters.
Pint-sized brothers Riley and Huey live with their granddad in suburbia, where they worry their African-American culture is being compromised every which way.
In this scene, rabble-rouser Huey tries to provoke wealthy white party-goers with a little revisionist history but gets nowhere.
(Soundbite of ""The Boondocks
(As Huey) And all I'm saying is Ronald Reagan was the devil.
Unidentified Man: You are such an articulate young man.
(As Huey) I'm trying to explain to you that Ronald Reagan was the devil.
Ronald Wilson Reagan.
Each of his names has six letters.
Six-six-six.
Man, doesn't that offend you?
That's right, the prime minister's comments were really the strongest that he has made since the November attacks.
However, from the very beginning, Indian officials have hinted that these are - first they called them - these attacks were the handiwork of, quote, ""elements inside Pakistan,"" end quote.
Then they - foreign ministry officials suggested that this couldn't have been done without real training from officials in Pakistan, specifically military and spy agency officials.
And yesterday, the prime minister made the strongest statement yet, implicating - saying that this must have happened with some official knowledge.
However, they have stopped short of naming anyone specifically or saying whether these were serving members of the Pakistani government or retired members of the Pakistani government.
This could well be that they don't have specific information along these lines, or simply that they are not making it public, and this is part of the diplomatic dance that's going on.
We have a caller on the line.
Let's go to Joel, Joel with us from Sacramento.
Hello.
Hi, Joel.
Hi.
I'm wondering how and who obtained these manuscripts?
How did these - how the manuscripts of these phone calls come about?
That's a good question.
These calls were intercepted.

The gunmen were talking on their - on cell phones - Indian cell phones with Indian SIM cards - and they were talking to what the Indian authorities say are Voice over Internet Protocol numbers that they believe were being used in Pakistan.
Did they say how they managed to record these intercepts, though?
They haven't provided any details, but clearly the SIM cards that these gunmen were using had been traced.
In other words, you know, there was some intelligence that pointed to these particular numbers that the attackers were using.

And this forms a principle piece of the dossier - not the entire - not all the conversations but sort of selected conversations that took place between the start of the attacks, which was the evening of November 26th, Wednesday.
And it goes almost - about 24 hours into it, up to about 10:25 on Thursday.
And after that, there are no more phone call transcripts, and that's a big mystery.
We don't know why.
Joel, thank you...
Which government exactly released - I'm just trying to figure out on which side did manuscripts originate from?
Which government released them?
It would have been the Indian government, I suspect.
OK, OK.
That's correct.
This is all according to the Indian government.
So, you've got - the so-called ""dossier"" includes selected portions of the telephone conversations.

It includes photographs of materials that were recovered from the gunmen and from the fishing trawler that they used to get to the shores of Bombay and GPS recordings - Global Positioning System that they used to navigate their way over and so on.
There's an Indian fishing boat - includes that - the dossier includes the allegation that they hijacked this on the high seas and murdered the crew.
That's right.
This was how they made their way, according to the Indians, from Karachi to Bombay.

So, first they got on a small ship in Karachi, then got on a bigger Pakistani boat - sorry, a small boat from Karachi, got on a bigger Pakistani boat - and then got on a fishing trawler - an Indian fishing trawler, killed four crew members, spared the captain, had the captain steer the way closer to Indian shores and then killed the captain on instructions from one of the supervisors.
And then they jumped into a dinghy - a motorized dinghy - each carrying backpacks fully loaded.
And each of the gunmen had a nine millimeter pistol, Kalashnikov, ammunition, a hand grenade, and each had a bomb packed with military-grade explosives.
And with this, they came on shore at about 8:30 on the night of the 26th.
And went to their various destinations.

There's also a terrifying intercept - moment from the interrogation of the sole survivor of the attackers, that's Mohammed Ajmal Kasab, who said that these 10 attackers who caused all this mayhem were, in fact, part of a larger group that had been trained all together.

This is perhaps the most frightening detail in this entire dossier and one that causes concern, naturally, to the Indians and other nations, because what Kasab allegedly says to his interrogators is, there were first 32 of us, who were trained in the making of bombs, in the handling of interrogation and in suicide bombing.
They were then apparently joined by three others who came from elsewhere, he doesn't know where, but they weren't part of the original training.
So, that was 35 total.
Six of them were sent to Indian-administered Kashmir for some kind of operation, he guesses.
Ten of them were sent to Bombay.
What happened to the rest?
Where are they?
Are they still in the game, as it were, is a mystery.
Jependra(ph) joins us on the line from Cincinnati.
Hi.
The detailed accounts given in the dossier are chilling, and I'm shocked.

I mean, if - and the nature of these attacks and the discipline with which they were carried out, it's - I think it is obvious that some Pakistani agency had to have some kind of involvement in this attack.
And I think this dossier proves that.
I mean, if the world did not already know that Pakistan harbors and encourages terrorism, I think this report is sufficient enough to prove to the world that this is what they do.
